<text>html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05C15 graph coloring; forbidden induced subgraph; linear forest; polynomial-time algorithm serial article Golovach, Petr A.; Paulusma, Daniël; Song, Jian Number: 6109939 4-coloring math1 -free graphs when math2 is small. 2013 Summary: The math3 -Coloring problem is to test whether a graph can be colored with at most math4 colors such that no two adjacent vertices receive the same color. If a graph math5 does not contain a graph math6 as an induced subgraph, then math7 is called math8 -free. For any fixed graph math9 on at most six vertices, it is known that 3-Coloring is polynomial-time solvable on math10 -free graphs whenever math11 is a linear forest, and NP-complete otherwise. By solving the missing case math12 , we prove the same result for 4-Coloring provided that math13 is a fixed graph on at most five vertices.</text>

We obtain bounds that are uniform in both math4 and the form itself. We also improve a bound on a sum of the form math5 , where the math6 are the Fourier coefficients of a holomorphic cusp form, math7 and math8 are any real numbers, and math9 . This last bound is uniform in math10 , but not with respect to the form.</text>

The kth power math5 of G is the graph with vertex set math6 such that two distinct vertices are adjacent in math7 if and only if their distance apart in G is at most k. A connected graph G is called super- math8 if every minimal vertex cut of G is the set of neighbors of some vertex in G. In this note, we consider the super-connectivity of the Kronecker products of several kinds of graphs and complete graphs. We show that D=G math9 is super- math10 for m math11 and G satisfying one of the following conditions: (1) G is a non-complete split graph with math12 ; (2) G is a power graph of a path math13 such that n math14 G is a power graph of a cycle math15 such that n math16 and n math17 .</text>

In this article, we prove that the conjecture is true when math6 .</text>

<text>html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05C90 05C12 05C07 92E10 additively weighted Harary index; join; composition; disjunction; symmetric difference serial article Alizadeh, Yaser; Iranmanesh, Ali; Došlić, Tomislav Number: 1254.05191 Additively weighted Harary index of some composite graphs. 2013 The paper under review introduces a modification of the Harary index of a connected graph. The Harary index of a connected graph math1 is math2 where math3 denotes the graph distance between the two vertices math4 . Such indices are sometimes applied in chemistry. For example, the Harary index of a single edge is 1. The aim of the new invariant is to give extra weight to vertices with large degree. Specifically, the paper studies the additively weighted Harary index math5 Here math6 is the degree of the vertex math7 . Thus, letting math8 and math9 denote respectively a complete graph and a star on math10 vertices, math11 and math12 . It is clear that adding an edge can only increase math13 , so the value for the complete graph is the maximum attainable: similarly a tree must have the smallest value. The authors use transformations on trees to show that amongst trees on math14 vertices, the path has the smallest math15 and the star the largest. They then discuss various “composite graphs”, i.e. graphs obtained by putting two other graphs together in some way. They obtain various formulae for the additively weighted Harary indices of various graphs in terms of additively weighted Harary indices of the two input graphs and the so-called Zagreb indices of the graphs. Some future directions for research are also indicated.</text>

Among applications, we shall count the number of solutions of the Diophantine equations math1 and math2 in positive integers under certain relative primality conditions.</text>

Among applications, we shall count the number of solutions of the Diophantine equations math1 and math2 in positive integers under certain relative primality conditions.</text>
